Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2014 02:24PM wintersocks wrote: Cheryl, This is the best news. Hooray for you and your family, and thanks for coming back and reminding us stage iii's that life can get good again.
Posts.Title: It's My 5 YEAR CANCERVERSARY !!!!!! victoriasecret Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2013 05:39AM wintersocks wrote: Hi all, I had my ooph Thurs just gone so I am 4 days post op (ouch!). i am strongly er: 8/8. I was advised by the onc that removal would make no difference to my risk of recurrance as mostly (post men) oestrogen is secreted from other areas. However, I did have a large ovarian cyst (been told endometriona) that has now gone, and I am pleased about that. Was told by one gynae it is harmless and will self resolve, another says ~we always get these out' - what to believe?? Interestingly, my left ovary had twisted on the tube and died anyway. When I questioned the doctor about this he told me that ovaries post-men often die and usually it is the left. I googled this and indeed it appears to be so! So all on all i had one removed plus tubes too. But I also needed other stuff done so for me it was a good decision to get them out.
Posts.Title: Ooph or not? mary625 mary625

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2013 03:00PM wintersocks wrote: Mary625, What an idiotic thing to say, I am so sick of docs/nurses thinking they can say what they like. I have whole bag of things I could pull out....that has been said to me.. Thank-you my post op is going ok. I am a little sore, but mainly hurts if I sneeze. I have a few strange things going on in my nether regions (feels like stitches??) but I know I have had a Transobturator Tape Procedure too and a right ureterolysis too (not sure what that is - will Google) and a posterior repair. So slightly more then an oophrectomy. It does not feel to be a major op as such. I have 3 plasters on my abdo, one at belly button and one low down centre and one slightly above to the left. I think this is the laporascopy incisions. I do not have the write up from the docs yet, just the discharge note. I have been told that I must not lift for 6 weeks..... I feel pleased I have had the ooph, one less thing to worry about. I am post men highly er + 8/8 and on Femara. Having said that one doc 'tut tutted' when he heard I was having it done. I am sorry to hear of your additional health problems, it's such a bore to have other stuff besides bc going on isn't it?
Posts.Title: Ooph or not? mary625 mary625

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2016 02:32AM wintersocks wrote: Dear Jacqueline and ElaineTherese, The turtles and rabbit analogy is very useful.. Thanks for that. I just sometimes think 'wow', it was such a whopper compared to others who talk about 'pea sized lumps' - I guess because I knew it was there before I did something about it makes me feel bad. I know I am at high risk for chest wall recurrence and cannot believe I have not yet.. Jacqueline, that is amazing you are so far along and it's great to hear you are doing so well! I am so pleased to hear this for you and your family, that you remain well. I think Christmas has a way of stirring up a lot of 'cancer emotions'. I am not quite 5 years but will be in August next year. Thanks, and Happy Holidays to you both.

Posts.Title: Postcard from the edge of ten years out.... weesa lifelover

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2012 07:26PM wintersocks wrote: Hi All, I too had neo adjuvant up to August of this year. EC and Tax. This is stiill not routine in the Uk. my tumour was large IDC E/R 8/8. On EC I was told there was a 'disappointing reponse from the chemo oncologist. I was then switched to TAX (4 in total). The lump did not disappear, but rather softenend. there was a disagreement between the chemo onc and the BS about response. The BS said in the end the response was 'excelllent'. I was left a little confused. My BS eventually explained that actually palpating/observing the lump was a more accurate indicator of reponse than over reliance of technology. She said that the clinical examination was just as if not more important than repeated scans and ultrasounds.   She was pleased so I guessed I should be. I had 4 positive nodes and whether the cancer was killed off in them I still don't know. I am still deeply traumatised by it all and have yet to look at my final path report. I had an MX and 15 rads and have just had my 1st NED. Christmas greetings to all from accross the pond. WS

I am 5 years in September, the hair loss has got slightly worse if anything.

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2012 09:17PM wintersocks wrote: Hello all, 4.50am here in the UK and I can't sleep again! Mumof 3 - Yes, I heard that the docs don't like to drain the seromas, but at this point mine is so uncomfortable! I feel like I have 'tyres' around me! also it looks like the mx is growing another boob. I phoned the nurse and she said come in and get it drained. She told me it will be painless and the relief will be .instant So I will be there at 11. How are things with you? Blessings20: Do you think the Anastrozole is causing you problems? I am 4 days on the Letrozole and so far so good, nothing to report. Can't believe we have to do this for 5 years though- I am very bad at taking tablets (disorganised!)  Beckers   Can relate to the depression stuff you speak of. I too let myself go and didn't attempt much. I put on loads of weight with chemo, I am trying to get motivated to walk, but I am finding the motivation has gone.....not sure how to get it back I do hope you are feeling a little better.  Marianeliza: Letrozole, Arimidex are hormone therapies. There are a few different kinds. Whether we are pre/post menopausal influences which we get, plus other factors. How are you and where are you up to with your treatment?   Hello to all others too. I feel so tired of breast cancer now. I know some still have a long way to go and we need to keep on keeping on! But it is so hard at times! Thinking of all who are in pain/discomfort/sad......tomorrow be another day and let's hope for better.   WS

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2012 07:33PM wintersocks wrote: Hello to All, 2.30am - here in the UK and as usual can't sleep again! Tazzy, - I am in the North now ( Bronte country - wild and windy Pennines) but I did live in London for many years, Camberwell and Brixton. Do you miss the UK? Blessings20- Thank-you for your lovely comforting words it really does help and your understanding  has given me the strength to tell the story that I have kept to myself for so long .  Here it is:  I have been at the breast clinic for many years on and off, with fibroadenomas, dense breasts, lumps and bumps. Indeed last time I was there 6 years ago for a lump on the left breast the doc cleared that as b9. On the right side (my now mx) he told me 'I don't like the look of this' I had mammo and ultrasound the radiographer told me I had a lymph node up that was 'probably a result of an infection'. I went on to have biopsies in that breast and was told it was 'normal breast tissue' and discharged.  Fast forward to 2012 and here I am with an mx, with at least one node and I have done neo-adjuvant chemo. When my breast started to look weird, grow hard, and distorted, I did not go back and I am sure was like this well over a year. I should have done and I should have questioned the 'lymph node issue' more closely than I did 6 years ago.  But I was having such a bad time in my life and I......didn't do what I should have.  Today, I had a missed phone call from my breast nurse, she tells me that all my histology results might be back by Friday and if they are she will phone me. I already know that it is a mixed ca lobular/ductal and grade 2 - although I have yet to be staged but at a 5cm mass I think it will be 3, (the staging is what really scares me), but I have a clear CT      There it's all out! and I feel better!! (but I have a snotty nose now, due to the blubbing!)  Mumofthree - I was touched by your story and what a difficult time you are having especially with managing largely on your own with the children. Surely there is some help you can get from an outside agency? You have too much to deal with. I have been there too with young children on my own and unwell (I also have an auto-immune illness as well). Please do know that there has been great support on here for me and I have only just joined. There is so much comfort in knowing that so many others are here with us, to help and share in those awful dark moments. I am sending you hugs across the waves(((MO3))  I hope all who are in pain and discomfort - find tomorrow a better day.  I will get that book that you all recommend.

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 04:40PM wintersocks wrote: Hello friends.  Becker's - Thank-you for your lovely thoughts Tazzy- It is such a small world eh? Whoops, I did that ignorant thing of assuming you were in USA, but indeed on looking again see your'e not! Anyway, it's good you are settled and don't miss blighty too much. Mumof3 - I am so pleased you managed to get some help - it was needed for you and your children. I'm pleased you said having fluid drained didn't hurt as I think I might need that done. I finally got my path report and here it is:  e/r+ (8/8) pr- her- 4/11 nodes IDC (6cm)  I was completely terrified going in. My surgeon is so lovely, she has such a calming way and it makes a huge difference doesn't it to get someone kind. I am so glad that is over and done with. I got a written report of the Path results but gave it to my partner to hide as I can't face looking at it! I think I am  a bit of a coward. My surgeon has put me on Letrozole as she prefers it to Arimidex apparently - wonder why that is. I have to have a bone scan in about a year as my recent DEXA scan revealed Osteopenia, AI can only worsen that. I am coming up to 2 weeks post op and I have to say I think my pain is increasing! Or maybe I am just not taking meds seriously (Paracetomal/Ibrufen only). The surgeon yesterday said I have a seroma too, but just to keep an eye on it if it becomes swollen or tight. Well, it is both of those! I wonder at which point I should get it seen to again? anyone else had this? Mu underarm is sore too, my ribs and round the back where the rains came out. My MX scar was revealed yesterday to as the dressing came off. It looks quite neat, there is a very small lump there that alarmed me a little, I am assuming it is just the stitches or something. It 's so difficult to know what to do about these bits and pieces that arise isn't it.  Perhaps I will call in at the drop in clinic next week and get all looked at by the nurse. Thank-you to all that supported me on what I think was an utterly terrifying day (Mon). I am so glad to be thru the other side.

I would just like to say to those who are anticipating drain removal that is really ok and over in a flash.  I am now 6 days post MX and boy the stiffness and pain! the nurse visited today and declared the wound site ok and will come back Thurs. I am still worrying about the final path report on Monday, I know it is something I have to do - but honestly I feel ill even before I have got into the consultant's room. Posts.Title: My Apologies Hopefloatsagainandagain wintersocks

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2013 10:42AM wintersocks wrote: Fenella, I was asked if I wanted to be copied in as a patient. I said yes, so I get everything that goes to my GP.  I have all my path reports, initial findings, treatment - plans and progression. I think this is pretty standard now across the NHS. Has your current consultation finished? Like you I had fibrocystic breasts, I asked what I should do if another lump/abnormality should show up after my consultation. The consultant's reply was that each finding (lump/bump inc stringy bits) had to be judged by itself irrespective of what had gone before. My advice is to go back to your GP and tell them of your new findings and insist on a re-referral. You could ask the GP for a copy  of the findings of your last breast clinic visit (I am sure they cannot refuse). If you go back to the breast clinic (and I advise you do, if only for peace of mind) ask if you might be copied in to all GP correspondence. I was actually asked if this was what I wanted. I am in West Yorkshire. Please don't just be worrying. go back again and again , until you are satisfied. I wish I had done.   Just ask if you want more info. WSx
Posts.Title: End of my tether don't know which way to turn fenella fenella

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2013 04:31AM wintersocks wrote: Fenella, I am in the UK and have had full reports on everything (breast cancer pathology). My hospital copies all to patient as well as GP as a matter of routine if you opt in for this. It must be possible for you to obtain your report.  After years of 'fibrocystic breasts' lumps/bumps/fibroadenomas then cancer.  - I wish I'd have had an MRI to spot it earlier. The least you can do is go back to your GP and ask for a 2nd opinion.  What you have is most likely harmless, but you need to conclusively know that. PM if you want more info
Posts.Title: End of my tether don't know which way to turn fenella fenella

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2015 05:14PM wintersocks wrote: kateink. I have had chemo too and Femara, for around two and a half years. following chemo, I was worried about the top coming in as it was slower than the rest of the growth. My hair like yours in much thinner on top than the sides or the back. I am certain this is the Femara. My hair used to be uncontrollable, and very very thick. I cannot believe when I run my hands through it just how thin it is. I have no underarm hair and no pubic hair either, I am assuming this is all down to Femara. I hope when I get off it things might improve, unless as current thinking ten years is better than five,

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2015 09:31AM wintersocks wrote: Tuffmama, my surgeon said survival starts when the cancer is removed: ie at surgery, so that is the date I go with, and it makes sense to me . I was dx three years ago in Feb 2012. However, I do not count til August, for that is when I actually had the mx following neoadjuvant chemo. There is always a debate about this, as I have seem it mentioned many times on BCO, different people count survivorship in different ways and times. But as I like and trust my surgeon I go with what she says. She knows more about it then I do. i hope that helps.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2013 01:47PM wintersocks wrote: LKSher, I found the questioning incredibly intrusive. It made me feel extremely anxious too, as I could tell they were 'processing my death' (and this was mostly from my sister) she wanted information that I didn't even know my self at that point. A few days post-dx before treatment I felt completely disorientated. I soon realised however, that I was potentially 'up' for public consumption. Not all of it caring, some of it just plain nosey. I realised I had the option to keep the details very private. That was very liberating.  I do not discuss the details, only with my closest friends. I hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2015 02:54AM wintersocks wrote: I would like to add for me it was a series of very 'stressful events' from childhood onwards rather than stress as in a hectic working life. I believe these influences to be somehow, in part related to my cancer dx. I cannot think that the mind and body are so separate that one has no influence on the other. Yet we know that equally strong, healthy people with no risk factors are dx too, that is hard to understand. For me, along with high oestrogen levels, general ill health, ethnicity and childhood poverty in my case, meant I was predisposed to major illness. I believe that all of this contributed to my cancer, in ways not yet known. The cure for cancer proves to be elusive and complex, then so is the cause. More research needed.

I am nearly due for a mammo (which I don't really trust) in finding further ca.   I want 2 or none. like you prefer tectonic shift,  I am two years since dx (nearly) tmurno, I was also told that removal of a healthy breast does not prevent recurrence (in either side)  or of course the development of mets.   It's all very difficult isn't it to make these decisions.

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2013 05:41AM wintersocks wrote: I am posting this in desperation as I am not sure what to do next. I will try to be brief. Finished treatment for BC NOV 12- last 3 month check NED. (next check 19th/9) Bone scan 1 month ago - NED ABDO and lower pelvic scan - last month NED. I am currently waiting an operation to remove a large ovarian cyst and an oophrectomy, I have a rectocele also 'Your bowel at the moment, is anatomically in the wrong place' - It is going to be pushed back as my v prolapse. Have had a CA125 test - results not known.  But I have stopped being fast tracked for the op. I am having treatment also related to bladder/bowel incontinence a new pioneering thing (needle in ankle) a 12 week course now finished.  I am also a Coeliac.  The thing is I am having very very bad pain under my left rib for the last 3 months only relieved by standing, it is constant, gnawing and very very uncomfortable.  And pain in my back (like indigestion) every day.  The gynae/colo-rectal surgeon said the MRI I recently had is clear.  NED, No worries. I have asked to see my gastro team to see if they can help and I am seeing them in 2 weeks. I am so down with all these health issues, I have 3 teams involved (breast/gynae/and soon gastro) I keep thinking it must be mets, I cannot think of another explanation. I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2016 09:31AM wintersocks wrote: Hello Chrissy and anyone else. I have had diarrhea for 10 days with some vomiting although that has stopped now. I saw my GP and he asked I provide a sample and then gave me rehydration sachets and loperamide capsules. I stopped the capsules for a day or 2 to see if I was better but unfortunately not. I am literally going to the loo at least once an hour. I have a massively diminished appetite also. I am a Coeliac and do not recall eating gluten which could be giving me the above symptoms, but I am pretty sure I have not, as I tend to have other symptoms alongside the tummy issues but I don't. Can this be a sign of seondary cancer for example in the liver? I am panicking right now, not least because I have a new job starting Weds and I just don't see how I can go like this. Also that there might be something serious going on. I would be grateful for any advice as to this being symptomatic of secondaries..

You know where our minds go when something is not resolving.....My GP did not say much just gave meds including one that stops vomiting, but he did give me an exam. petjunkie, thanks for that info, yes I am keeping hydrated, but as soon as I drink or shortly after I need the loo.... (TMI!) Thanks for reassurances too. Thanks

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2018 02:02PM wintersocks wrote: Hi Ladies I saw the GP about 3 weeks ago and had some blood tests which I was told today were clear. I explained to the receptionist that I had still had intermittent arm pain still and what was i to do about that? She said she would get a GP to call me and todaY, she called and said she had he letter in front of her form the Prof of onc (he must have seen the blood test results) and she said he says something like poss mets to chest wall and that I need reviewing and an MRI might be then ordered, So she says can you come into tomorrow for a thorough physical exam and I said no. meetings at work tomorrow. So she says Thursday and i said yes. so at 6 it is. She asked me about the pain: it is intermittent and sometimes goes for weeks and then is back and goes from shoulder to hands/fingers and up/down the arm (cancer side) and is a real deep pain. then it goes again. Says she: mets pain is constant and tends to get worse over time and it doesn't sound particularly worrying. but let's have a look at you. I told her that no one had contacted me either about the Onc letter or blood tests. She apologises and says 'Yes you seem to have drifted' sorry. The NHS here in Blighty is a real mess - but really if I had not been in touch I would have been left. It's my eldest sons birthday today he's 24 and honestly I don't know how I stopped from crying when I spoke with him on the phone to wish him HB ; I didn't tell him about the latest. Any thoughts any one? Please.

Posts.Title: Permanent hair loss from Taxol? Sneakychiquita tetonfun

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2015 12:15PM wintersocks wrote: momnorth, my right breast shrunk dramatically, to become at least 2 cup sizes smaller. I was subsequently dx with breast cancer. My surgeon immediately recognised something was very wrong. It was my right breast which i had had many b9 issues prior to the cancer dx. I did not have any itching, but I did subsequently develop a really painful shooting, like lightening pain. the nipple was permanently protruding too. I am not sure if this is an unusual presentation of breast cancer, but I was not really aware that breast size changing shape to either larger or smaller could be a sign of breast cancer. I was always told to look for a lump. I do hope the breast specialist is able to put your mind at rest as soon as possible to what is actually going on. Please try not to overly panic! This is my story not yours. It is virtually impossible to diagnose anything over the internet, and I repeat this is only what happened to me.
Posts.Title: Shrinking breast Momnorth104 Momnorth104

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2013 03:56PM wintersocks wrote: Ladies, Thanks so much for your replies. It really does help knowing I am not alone with this whopping tumour. However, I did know there was something wrong, but took a time to get round to it because of other ongoing problems (some health, some other stuff). Now I just feel incredibly guilty that I seemed to ignore it. Mainly, because of my sons 18 and 15yrs. But, I had been at the breast clinic for years prior to this with lumps/bumps fibroadenomas and even a biopsy 6 years or so ago in the breast that was mx'd last year. I am worrying that I/we have a worse prognosis because of the large lump. My BS has told me she doesn't expect it to recurr. I realise I am still fairly new to this have only finished RADS in Nov. Cheryl - How nice to hear you are doing well. Hiya Liv from Perth   Iago - the dense tissue does seem to be a problem, this was my issue too  - If only they would MRI those of us with dense breasts.

Posts.Content: May 8, 2015 05:23PM wintersocks wrote: 2 lumps post diep on the mx scar. 1 biopsied and was fat necrosis. 2nd lump to be biopsied on the 29th. I am my ps agree without hesitation, that because of my dx, it and any other lumps I get must be biopsied. If you are really concerned it's probably the only way to be 100% sure that it is necrosis.
Posts.Title: Stage 3 anxiety fear of reacurrence Carolehebert RSS

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2014 09:44AM wintersocks wrote: jbokland, Great question! The advice I gave myself was to give up control and try to trust those that care for me. Also to listen to that one breath at a time, in and out, slowly concentrate on getting through the next minute, never mind tomorrow or a year or 2 hence.The abject terror on first learning you have cancer will subside. It really will. Choose very carefully those you surround yourself with, I dispensed with the weepers and the wailers and the pseudocarers 'the let-me-know-if you-need anythingers' I needed people to do practical, make the fire, cook dinner.... those offers were very thin on the ground. I felt worn out meeting their needs. Come here, it's such a comfort, it is where I gained my strength to get up in the morning.
